channel.name: Question about zkApp Account Manager for making a Wrapped Mina Token

messages.content:
I'm working on making a WrappedMina token contract towards a new tutorial on zkApp Account Managers.

I'm running into a few questions when making a method that allows a user to send MINA tokens to the WrappedMina token contract, and receive back WMINA

I'm trying to do this by creating a transaction that does the following:
1. Create an account update that sends MINA from the user to the WrappedMina token contract
2. Check inside the WrappedMina token contract that Mina tokens were received at the contract
3. If so, Mint WMINA tokens for the user from inside the WrappedMina token contract.

I'm getting stuck at the right way to implement this though - I've made an attempt, which can be found here, with this [https://github.com/es92/zkApp-examples/blob/0a7fa47a7188f8bfcde89775cdcd0ee91538d61e/14-zkApp-manager-accounts/src/main.ts#L89] attempting to do step (1) above, and this attempting to do steps 2 & 3 above [https://github.com/es92/zkApp-examples/blob/0a7fa47a7188f8bfcde89775cdcd0ee91538d61e/14-zkApp-manager-accounts/src/WrappedMina.ts#L78].

I'm getting errors on both steps - for 1 (commenting out the call to *mintWrappedMinaWithoutApprove*), I get:
* Error: [[],[["Cancelled"]],[["Update_not_permitted_balance"]]]

And for 2/3, I get errors for:
* [["Token_owner_not_caller"]],[["Account_balance_precondition_unsatisfied"]],[["Invalid_fee_excess"]]]

I'm assuming there's just an alternative way to do all of this, but would be great to know the correct way! Thanks
Are the permissions on the wrapped mina contract set to allow receiving Mina?

you can find a working token example here: https://github.com/stove-labs/zk-htlc

however i didnt try combining working with native/custom token inside one contract

There is this issue: https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/issues/638

Which caused the same issue for me in the past.  I think you need to sign the account update, but only because it's on `LocalMina`, and the account permissions are not the same default as real accounts.

edit 1 - It looks like you are signing the account update from the test account though, so maybe not...
edit 2 - actually the fix is to add `.requireSignature();` not just sign it... which you aren't doing, so maybe... 🙂

embeds.title: Make test accounts have normal permissions · Issue #638 · o1-labs/s...
embeds.description: Repro steps: Fill in a user private key in this script and attempt to run (private key must be to a funded account on Berkeley). Expected behavior is that the funded account will send the smart con...

messages.content: how would you do that? i thought every account has a specific tokenId, and thats why it can operate with that token balances

There is a permission to receive, which I think is set, by default, to any.  I don't know.  I actually also don't know if it is different per account or not!  Not related to this issues I think.  I just saw `Update_not_permitted_balance` and thought maybe the permission was invalid to receive funds.
the way i understood it is that any account updates changing a contract with a custom tokenId, must be approved/wrapped/child of the actual tokenId contract itself. thats what the .approve() api does
But the first account update is the user sending mina to the wmina contract.  So even a normal mina transaction can fail if the contract is not allowed to receive mina.

Got the first part, nice! Was permission related. Had it set to `proof` for `WrappedMina`'s `receive` - changing it to the default fixed that part - `requireSignature` ended up not needed with that either. On to the second half
Thanks @mahroot_OKEx @45930
Okay rest working now!
Would be great to know if this is a sensible way to implement this though @gregor when you get a chance
Yeah I think that's broadly a sensible way, but I have a few remarks. I can put them together in form of a PR?
`mintWrappedMinaWithoutApprove` could just create the depositing account update itself
then getting the balance change would be direct
`mintWrappedMinaApprove` can take the `destination` from the `receiveMinaAccountUpdate` (which should be called `depositMinaAccountUpdate`)
well, if we want to make the assumption that the user uses the same address for their MINA & token accounts..

but for a tutorial I'd say that's fine
```ts
let destination = receiveMinaAccountUpdate.body.publicKey;
```

the mina token id is 1, not 0. you can get it from snarkyjs:
```ts
let minaTokenId = Token.Id.default;
```
all of the `approve` methods should check that the approved update matches the token id
(approveUpdateAndSend doesn't do that, I think that's a bug in my dex implementation! you did it right :D)

> mintWrappedMinaWithoutApprove could just create the depositing account update itself
it should use `AccountUpdate.createSigned` for that, not just `create`! because the depositing update needs a signature from the user

some other little things:
* `mintWrappedMinaApprove` doesn't update `this.priorMina`
* the `init()` method seems like it's pointless
Oh one more thing @evan! `mintWrappedMinaApprove` doesn't increment the MINA balance on the token owner account.
actually I think `mintWrappedMinaApprove` is missing `approve`. but approve doesn't actually make any sense for the use case!
so the method can be removed IMO

the pattern of passing an account udpate and approving it is only needed for the case that there is
1. a zkApp
2. which holds custom tokens
3. and needs to send these tokens elsewhere as part of one of its methods

in the case of `mintWrappedMinaApprove`, condition 2) is not met: The account update that's passed in doesn't hold custom tokens, it holds MINA tokens
Yeah getting this in a PR would be great!

Re what you mention on when approve is needed - I think I'm running into that on `redeemWrappedMinaWithoutApprove` - calling that method from a zkApp, causes the line `this.token.burn({ address: source, amount })` to make the error `Cannot add signature for...`.

Which makes sense, because if the `WrappedMina` contract tries to burn tokens on another account, it make sense that that account should have to approve that burn. If I'm understanding the approving system right - the reason for the approval being - a token manager contract *must* be in the loop for any token operations - but if that token manager contract wants to touch tokens it doesn't directly own, it needs to get permission from that other account too. 

I wonder, would it make sense to have an API where instead of the token manager permissioning the token holder to do anything with the token with `approve`, and then limiting what they can do by exclusion (enforcing particular requirements on the `AccountUpdate`) - what if instead the token holder permissioned the token manager to do particular operations on their account? Eg saying - you can send my tokens wherever you want - or you can burn my tokens if you want. May limit the risk of the token manager approving something they shouldn't (and feeling more intuitive to me at the moment).

Not sure if this is feasible with the implementation under the hood though. Now that I'm getting it, feels like something that can be emulated pretty easily at the API level in any case - in the tutorial I should perhaps be clear to give an example where if you want an AccountUpdate to *only* be approved to burn tokens on the token holder for example, what to limit on the AccountUpdate to ensure that is the case.

Curious if I'm getting it right and if above makes sense.

I'll play with the approve approach in the meantime too to get that call (`redeemWrappedMinaWithoutApprove`) working
@gregor

Actually, still a question above why does `redeemWrappedMinaWithoutApprove` work when called directly from a transaction, but not from a zkApp? https://github.com/es92/zkApp-examples/blob/c164c888748d324f1bf62179edaac935961c22fd/14-zkApp-manager-accounts/src/main.ts#L118

Is it because a user is "allowed" to permission these changes to themselves, but a user calling a zkApp can't permission the zkApp to allow those changes transitively so it has to be done explicitly somehow? A bit fuzzy. Would be great to know what is happening under the hood to make this happen (call stack related?)

Okay, just one more! Tried implementing the "with approve" version here, but don't have anything working yet - any tips on how to implement this so the burn can get approved? Tried to mirror the DEX example but must be missing something https://github.com/es92/zkApp-examples/blob/b79eab35427a779be24db97a03ce6b96b8d8412b/14-zkApp-manager-accounts/src/TokenPool.ts#L56
@maht0rz @gregor @evan has this issue been resolved or still a WIP?
Has been resolved, we got it all working in Evan's repo
